keyTakeAways: Federal officials, including Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), are under judicial scrutiny for allegedly violating a court order restricting the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago.

US District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order requiring body-worn cameras and restricting crowd control tactics, citing concerns that agents deployed tear gas without warning protesters.

Officials have claimed compliance with the camera mandate, with over 200 CBP agents in Chicago required to wear body cameras, but the judge remains unconvinced due to reports of tear gas deployment without prior warning.

Operation Midway Blitz, a Trump administration immigration crackdown, resulted in over 1,000 arrests across Illinois, fueling public protests and legal challenges to the tactics used by federal agents.
The judge has ordered depositions of Russell Hott (former ICE head in Chicago) and Gregory Bovino (CBP chief patrol agent) to obtain firsthand accounts of events during the protests.

Despite federal claims of compliance and denials of tear gas use without warning, the judge expressed serious concerns that her order is not being followed, and will continue to request accountability from officials.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge in Chicago, Sara Ellis, is investigating whether federal immigration enforcement agents under the Trump administration are complying with her order to restrict the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests. The judge, who previously required body-worn cameras for all agents, expressed serious concerns after reports indicated that agents used tear gas on demonstrators without prior warning. Operation Midway Blitz, a large-scale ICE enforcement operation in Chicagoland from September 8 to October 3, 2025, resulted in over 1,000 arrests and intensified protests. Officials including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers testified, asserting compliance with camera mandates and denials of unauthorized tear gas use, but the judge remains unconvinced. She has ordered depositions of Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino to obtain firsthand accounts of events. Protests continue at the Broadview ICE facility, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and 15 arrests reported in recent days, highlighting ongoing tensions between federal immigration enforcement and civil society.
title: Federal officials try to reassure judge they’re following her orders to tone down and record Chicagoland protest actions
